To study effects of different acid treatments with HZSM-5 zeolites on the chemistry of framework, acid nature, performance, and coke formation for methanol-to-hydrocarbon reaction, HZSM-5 with different Si/Al ratio were post treated with two different acid solutions (tartaric acid and ammonium hexafluorosilicate). After the post treatment with hexafluorosilicate (HZn-HF), it was found the extensive decrease in all kinds of acid sites owing to the non-selective dealumination, whereas the noticeable decrease in weak Lewis acid sites was found after the post treatment with tartaric acid (HZn-TA) resulted by the selective removal of the surface alumium. The result of the distingushed removal of Al from the bare HZSM-5 zeolites (HZn) also attributed the change in product selectivity for the MTH reaction as follows; high carbon distributions to the C2–C4 range olefins and low carbon distribution to C10+ species from the HZn-HF samples whereas high carbon distribution to BTEX from the HZn-TA samples. Analysis of the spent catalysts revealed the amount and chemistry of carbon deposits formed during the MTH reaction are directly related to the acidic nature of the HZSM-5 catalysts. For example, the amount of carbon deposit from the spent catalysts were found to be increased in the order: HZn-TA > HZn > HZn-HF. Therefore, among the bare and acid modified HZ catalysts, the HZn-HF type catalyst showed the least carbon deposition despite requiring the longest reaction time for the methanol conversion to reach 80%. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords ZSM-5 Acid modification Methanol-to-hydrocarbons Deactivation Catalyst lifetime Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Current global energy policies and scientific technology are geared towards reducing greenhouse gasses and breaking away from the dependence on fossil fuels [1–3]. In accordance with this trend, technologies related to the conversion of methanol into useful compounds have attracted great interest. Methanol can be obtained in large quantities from syngas, which can be easily produced from coal gasification, methane reforming, biomass, and steel production [3–6]. Syngas may be converted into value-added compounds through the well-known Fisher Tropsch (FT) process. However, the product obtained from the FT reaction requires an additional upgrading process [6,7]. Hence, the conversion of methanol to final products is economically competitive [8–10]. Recently, the process of converting methanol to value-added hydrocarbons (methanol-to-hydrocarbons, MTH), such as light olefins (MTO) or aromatics (MTA), over solid acid catalysts has been widely investigated in an effort to develop sustainable energy sources [11,12]. Aromatics such as benzene (B), toluene (T), and xylene (X) are important raw materials in the petrochemical industry because their demand has been increasing worldwide owing to the production of various chemicals, including fuels, solvents, and polymers. Traditionally, aromatics are produced via catalytic reforming and pyrolysis in petroleum processes. In order to develop alternative non-petroleum-based routes, the methanol to aromatics (MTA) process has received considerable attention over the past few decades [12,13]. MTH technology has been demonstrated in pilot plants in China, but there are still many technical issues to be solved [14]. For example, one of the problems is the fast deactivation of the catalyst due to rapid coke deposition [15]. Zeolite-based catalysts, which are solid-acid materials, are the main catalysts used in the methanol conversion reaction. The selectivity for the target product varies depending on the type of zeolite [12,16]. ZSM-5 zeolite is the most active catalyst for the MTH reaction, owing to the acidity and shape-selectivity of the catalyst [17]. Nonetheless, condensed aromatics generated on the acid sites of ZSM-5 can be trapped in micropores due to diffusion limitations, leading to accelerated coke deposition [8,18]. To overcome these problems, many studies have been conducted to improve the lifetime of the catalyst by adjusting the acid and diffusion properties of the zeolite [19–21]. Among various methods of post treatment, dealumination is one method of improving the stability of zeolite-based catalysts for hydrocarbon-related reactions by modifying the acid nature of bare zeolites [22,23]. This process can be classified into selective and non-selective dealumination depending upon the removal of the surface framework aluminum [24,25]. For the former process, dealumination of the zeolite framework can be achieved by either steaming at elevated temperature or using chelating agents, such as ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) or tartaric acid, in solution to selectively remove the surface framework aluminum [26–29]. In addition, various methods, such as steaming, acid treatment, and vapor phase treatment, can be used for the latter process as well [28,30,31]. Regardless of the dealumination method, dealuminated zeolite-based catalysts were reported to exhibit greatly enhanced stability [24,29,32]. In this context, we also prepared selectively and non-selectively dealuminated HZSM-5 catalysts to investigate and provide clearer evidence of the effect of the selective and non-selective dealumination on the catalytic performance including stability and coke formation as well as carbon distribution to product molecules during the MTH process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Modification of acidity of ZSM-5 zeolite In order to prepare dealuminated HZSM-5 catalysts, Commercial NH4-ZSM-5 zeolites were purchased from Zeolyst (CBV 3024E with SiO2/Al2O3=30 and CBV 5524 G with SiO2/Al2O3=50). All the samples were calcined in a muffle furnace at 600 °C for 6 h under airflow to obtain HZSM-5 samples. For removal of the surface Al sites, the prepared HZSM-5 sample was added into 1 M of tartaric acid (Samchun Chemical, > 99.5%) solution with solution (mL) to powder (g) ratio of 20, and the mixture were stirred at 60 °C for 4 h. The obtained white slurry was washed with de-ionized water multiple times, dried at 110 °C overnight, and finally calcined in the furnace at 600 °C for 6 h. For non selective removal of framework Al, the HZSM-5 powder was added into 0.1 M of ammonium hexafluorosilicate (Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) with the same solution to powder ratio above, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. After that, it was washed, dried, and calcined under the same conditions mentioned above. These prepared catalysts were denoted as HZn for the bare ZSM-5, HZn-TA for the selectively dealuminated ZSM-5, and HZn-HF for non-selectively dealuminated ZSM-5 respectively, and n represents Si/Al ratio of the ZSM-5. 2.2 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a D/MAX IIIB X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiations operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. All Data were recorded in the 2θ range of 5–60° with a step size of 0.02° and counting time of 3 s per step. The Si/Al ratio was determined using an X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy (Thermo/ARL QUANT'X) equipped with a Si(Li) crystal with Peltier cooling detector. A vacuum condition was used applied to avoid electron scattering. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter were calculated from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms obtained at liquid N2 temperature using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system. Prior to the adsorption measurements, all samples were degassed in vacuum at 300 °C for 4 h. The pore size distributions of the samples were obtained by applying the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the samples were obtained using a Zeiss Ultraplus Thermal Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope. Temperature-programmed NH3 desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements were carried out on an Autochem II 2920 of Micromeritics instrument to determine acidity of the prepared catalysts. The sample was pretreated at 600 °C under 50 mL/min flow of pure He for 1 h. Afterwards, 15 vol% NH3 in He was introduced at 100 °C for 30 min followed by He purging at the same temperature to remove physically absorbed NH3 molecules. Finally, zeolite was heated up to 600 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C /min under flow of He to measure desorbed NH3. Pyridine (Py) adsorption-desorption and 2,6-di‑tert-butylpyridine (2,6-DTBPy) experiments were carried out to determine not only total and external acidity but also Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The experiment was conducted in a stainless steel variable temperature gas flow transmission cell using a Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride-B detector (Nicolet Nexus 4700). 30 mg of the powder samples were prepared as self-supporting pellets with a diameter of 13 mm and placed in the cell. After the pretreatment at 250 °C to remove adsorbed water, pyridine vapor was flowed into the cell from a saturator with flowing pure He gas at 150 °C for 20 min. Then, pure He gas was purged through the cell at 150 °C for 3 h to remove any physically adsorbed pyridine molecules prior to the collection of the IR spectra. The IR spectra were recorded from 1400 cm−1 to 1700 cm−1, and both chemisorbed pyridinium ion (PyH+) on Brønsted acid sties and pyridine bonded on Lewis acid sites (PyL) were quantified at 1545 cm−1 and 1455 cm−1, respectively. The extinction coefficients were taken to be 1.13 cm·μmol−1 (PyH+) and 1.28 cm·μmol−1 (PyL), respectively for estimation of acid sites [33]. The quantity of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites were calculated from the formula presented below (Beer–Lambert's law): C = A ε * S m * 1000 where C is the concentration of acid sites (μmol·g − 1), A is the area of band (cm−1), S is the surface of the wafer (cm2), ε is the molar extinction coefficient (cm·μmol−1), and m is the mass of sample (mg). For calculating the concentration of external acid sites, molar extinction coefficient (εB = 1.67 cm/μmol) of 2,6-DTBPy IR band at 1616 cm−1 was used to determine the quantity of the external Brønsted acid sites [34]. The adsorption of 2,6-DTBPy proceeded at 150 °C for 30 min followed by 1 h degassing at the same temperature and by collection of the spectrum at room temperature. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a SDT Q600 in TA instruments to investigate carbon decomposition during the reaction. The spent catalyst collected after the reaction was heated in a 100 ml/min air flow at a rate of 10 °C /min until 1000 °C. To investigate carbon decomposition during the MTA reaction, we performed elemental analysis (EA) and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of the spent catalysts. Prior to analysis, used catalyst collected after the reaction was treated with N2 at 100 °C to remove weakly chemisorbed carbon species. Analyses of the C and H elements on the sample were conducted using a Thermo Scientific Flash 2000 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The TGA data was recorded on a SDT Q600 in TA instruments. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra of the catalysts were obtained by using PerkinElmer (Frontier model) equipped with a deuterated triglycine sulfate (DTGS) and Mercury-Cadmium-Telluride (MCT) detector. 60 mg of mixed ZSM-5(fresh and spent)/KBr powder was pressed into pellets with a diameter of 13 mm. IR spectrum of the ZSM-5 catalyst was collected from 450 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1 at room temperature. 2.3 Catalytic performance on methanol to hydrocarbons All catalytic tests were performed in a stainless steel fixed bed reactor. In each case, 1 g of sieved (425–850 µm) zeolitic catalyst was loaded in the center of the reactor. The catalyst bed was activated in pure N2 at 400 °C for 1 h prior to the reaction. The liquid methanol (Samchun Chemical, 99.5%) feedstock was introduced with flow rate of 0.1 mL/min by using syringe pump (Younglin YL 9200) under 100 mL/min flow of pure N2, and thereby the molar ratio of methanol and N2 in the reactant mixture was approximately 2:1. All experiments were conducted at 1 bar and 400 °C. The reaction mixture was analyzed by Gas chromatograph (Younglin 6100GC) equipped with Rtx-DHA column (0.25 mm ID x 100 m, Restek) and a flame ionization detector. The methanol conversion and carbon distribution were calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) Methanol conversion ( % ) = Methanol in − Methanol out Methanol in x 100 (2) Carbon disribution ( % ) = Ci ∑ product x 100 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Properties of the bare and acid treated ZSM-5 samples The Si/Al ratios of the bare and dealuminated ZSM-5 zeolites were characterized by X-ray fluorescence (XRF), revealing that the Si/Al ratio increased after dealumination regardless of the original Si/Al ratio and dealumination method (Si/Al = 17.9 for HZ30, 18.2 for HZ30-TA, 27.4 for HZ30-HF, 25.6 for HZ50, 26.8 for HZ50-TA, and 33.4 for HZ50-HF). Furthermore, the Si/Al ratios of HZn-HF samples were found to be higher than those of the HZn-TA samples. This is a rational result because dealumination using a chelating agent occurs only on the surface of the sample due to the size of the molecule [26,35]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 , showing the characteristic peaks of ZSM-5 zeolite with a typical MFI structure at 7–9° and 23–25° Integration of the characteristic peaks in the range of 23–25° indicated no change in the crystallinity of all the dealuminated catalysts whereas a slight change in the chemistry of the MFI framework was apparent. For example, for the HZ30-TA and HZ50-TA samples, in which only the surface acid sites were removed, the diffraction peak did not shift, whereas for HZ30-HF and HZ50-HF, where the aluminum sites in the framework were non-selectively removed, the peak shifted toward higher 2θ by 0.1° This could be regarded as a result of a shrinkage of the framework unit cell, albeit the small XRD peak shift, after dealumination and resilication without changing their crystallinity. The textural properties of the prepared catalysts, deduced from the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S1), are summarized in Table 1 . The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, pore volume (including micro- and mesopores), and pore size did not change after the acid treatment, in comparison with those of the HZ30 and HZ50 catalysts. The XRD and BET data indicate that dealumination itself does not affect the shape of the zeolite crystal or pore structure by chemical reconstruction of the framework. For example, in the case of post-treatment for desilication using alkali solution, the silicon atoms constituting the structural framework melt and the structure is degraded; cracks are formed on the crystal surface or mesopores are formed, and thereby leading to a reduction in relative crystallinity [36]. On the other hand, the proper dealumination-resilication of ZSM-5 samples induces less change in physical properties as only impurities are removed outside the framework. SEM images of the prepared samples are shown in Fig. 2 . The bare HZSM-5 samples (HZ30 and HZ50) comprised cubic and prismatic crystallites of ∼1 µm in size. No specific changes were observed in the surface and morphology of any of the HZSM-5 samples after the post acid treatment, which is in accordance with the XRD and N2 adsorption and desorption results. Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was used to investigate the acidity of the bare and post aicd treated HZSM-5 samples. The sum of the weak and strong acid sites quantified in the two areas are summarized in Table 2 . Regardless of the Si/Al ratio, the bare HZSM-5 samples possessed the largest number of weak and strong acid sites, resulting in the highest number of total acid sites. After the post acid treatment, the total number of acids decreased by approximately 47, 44, 14, and 7% for HZ30-HF, HZ50-HF, HZ30-TA, and HZ50-TA, respectively, compared to the bare HZn samples. Regardless of the Si/Al ratio and the type of the acid solution used, the number of weak acid sites was reduced by ∼50% after the post treatment. On the other hand, the number of reduced strong acid sites in HZn-HF samples was 4–5 times more than those in the HZn-TA samples. The acid quantity determined by Py-IR and 2,6-DTBPy-IR experiment (Fig. S2.) also shows similar trend to the NH3-TPD results (Table 2). However, it is noteworthy that the quantity of total Lewis acid sites, especially weak Lewis acid sites, can be more noticeable from all the acid treated samples. Furthermore, a decrease in the weak Lewis acid sites from HZn-HF samples was found to be higher than HZn-TA samples. This can be interpreted as the result of washing away the extra framework Al, which is mainly present on the zeolite surface, during the post acid treatment process [37,38]. The acid treatment also leaded to a decrease in the both entire and surface Brønsted acid sites, and the HZn-HF samples possess less remained Brønsted acid sites, about 60% remained for both the weak and strong sites, than the HZn-TA samples. Additionally, a decrease in the strong Brønsted acid sites from the HZn-TA samples were found to be only 10%. Strong Brønsted acid sites of ZSM-5 zeolite is known to originate framework Al sites in the pore, particularly channel intersection or neighboring Al sites, rather than the surface [39,40]. The quantity of the external acid sites was found to significantly decreased after the post acid treatment, and particularly a decrease in the acid sites from the HZn-TA was the most severe. Therefore, it can be concluded that in the case of selective dealumination, the acid sites on the surface of the ZSM-5 crystals, which are mainly classified as weak acid sites, can be more selectively removed, whereas non-selective dealumination resulted in a greater decrease in the acid sites regardless of the acid type and location. This conclusion is also in accordance with the previous research that defined acid properties of zeolite materials after selective and non-selective removal of Al sites [24]. 3.2 Stability and selectivity during MTH reaction The MTH reaction was carried out over the prepared HZSM-5 catalysts at atmospheric pressure and 400 °C. For all cases, the MTH reaction proceeded until the methanol conversion decreased from 100 to 80%, after which the HZSM-5 catalyst was collected from the reactor tube for further characterization. As presented in Fig. 3 , the bare HZSM-5 (HZ30 and HZ50) maintained the methanol conversion of 100% for the shortest time. In the case of the HZ50, 100% methanol conversion could be maintained for 38 h, which is 18 h longer than that of the HZ30 catalyst. In the case of the catalysts subjected to selective removal of the acid sites (HZ30-TA and HZ50-TA), 100% methanol conversion could be maintained for almost the same length of time as that of the HZ30 and HZ50 catalysts, whereas for the catalysts subjected to non-selective removal of the acid sites (HZ30-HF and HZ50-HF), 100% conversion was maintained for 48 h and 90 h, respectively, after the start of the reaction, where these times are significantly longer than for the other two types of catalysts. The carbon fractions of the hydrocarbon products, such as methane (CH4); C2–C5 range paraffins; C2–C4 range olefins; C5–C6 range olefins; benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene (BTEX); C9 aromatics; and C10+ (but mostly aromatics) species, generated by the HZn catalyst series during the MTH are presented in Fig. 4 . For the HZ30 catalyst series, the HZ30 exhibited the highest carbon distribution to paraffin (38%) among the initial products, followed by BTEX and C5–C6 range olefins. For the both HZ30-HF and HZ30-TA, the carbon distribution to paraffins at the initial time dropped by approximately 10%, reached the same value as the BTEX production, and decreased continuously during the given reaction time. In the case of HZ30-HF, the carbon distributions to the C2–C4 range olefins was noticeably high and reached up to 37% at 52 h on stream, which was about 15% higher than those from HZ30 and HZ30-TA samples. On the other hand, the carbon distribution to C10+ unknown species at the initial period was found to be the highest from the HZ30-TA among HZ30 series samples, and also decreased gradually. In the case of the HZ50 series catalyst, carbon distributions during the MTH reaction basically followed similar trends to those from the HZ30 series samples; 1) the gradual decrease in paraffins and BTEX production, 2) low production of methane and C9 aromatics, 3) noticeably high carbon distributions to the C2–C4 range olefins from the HZ50-HF sample, 4) the lowest carbon distribution to C10+ species from the HZ50-HF among HZ50 series samples. It is noteworthy that the selective removal of framework aluminum of the bare ZSM-5 catalyst brought about the change in the product selectivity in the MTH reaction under the assumption that there was no shape selectivity effect by changing in the pore structure or the occurrence of mesopores due to the post acid treatment. When the framework aluminum of the bare ZSM-5 was removed non-selectively, the carbon distribution into paraffins and BTEX was significantly reduced, while the carbon distribution into C2–C4 range olefins was greatly increased. On the other hand, in selectively removal of the surface aluminum, the carbon distribution into C10+ species, most of which were composed of aromatics, increased, and this trend was found clearer from HZ30 series samples. It is generally known that the MTH reaction starts at the dehydration of methanol and then hydrocarbon pool mechanism follows to produces various hydrocarbon intermediates in the chain growth step [16,41]. For a sequence chain growth of the hydrocarbon intermediates formed during the initial stage of the MTH reaction, the strength and density of acid sites are required to be strong and high enough otherwise the hydrocarbon intermediates tend to undergo a hydrogen exchange reaction and finally convert into light olefins [42,43]. This can be the case of HZn-HF catalysts, and as a result, the high carbon distribution into C2–C4 range olefins is also reasonable. On the other hand, the reaction pathway to aromatic products during the MTH reaction is known to be related not only to the acid properties but also to the position of aluminum in the zeolite framework [9,39,44]. Hence, it can be concluded that the selective removal of the surface Al sites (HZn-TA type samples)resulted in an increase in the selectivity to aromatic products in the MTH reaction by further increasing the ratio of framework Al in the channel to the overall framework Al. 3.3 Characteristics of coke The decrease in the activity of zeolite-based catalysts in all types of hydrocarbon conversion reactions, including the MTH reaction, is strongly related to the formation of carbon deposits (so-called coke) on the surface and in the pores of the zeolite catalysts [45,46]. Hence, the HZ30 and HZ50 series catalysts were collected after the MTH reaction, and the nature of the carbonaceous deposit formed on each zeolite catalyst was characterized by TGA, elemental analysis, and FT-IR. As shown in Fig. 5 , the TGA curves of all the HZSM-5 catalysts exhibited weight losses of 15–21%, and because the analysis was performed under flowing air, it can be expected that the loss was caused by oxidation of the carbon material formed on the surface of the spent catalysts [47]. However, the shape of the TGA curve for each catalyst was slightly different. In the case of the HZ30 type catalysts, when the surface acid sites were selectively removed (HZ30-TA), the weight loss occurred rapidly around 550 °C, whereas in the case of the HZ30-HF type catalysts, the weight loss was less than that of HZ30 in all temperature ranges. The same weight loss trend was also observed for the HZ50 series catalyst as well. The weight loss from the spent catalysts based on the TGA analysis and C formation rate were summarized in Table 3 . For all the spent HZSM-5 catalysts, the weight loss and C formation rate increased in the order: HZn-TA > HZn > HZn-HF. This apparently indicates that the formation rate as well as the amount of carbon deposition were lowest on the HZn-HF type catalysts.The H/C molar ratios of the carbon deposits from all the spent catalysts are summarized in Table 3. For all the spent HZSM-5 catalysts, the ratio decreased in the order: HZn-TA > HZn > HZn-HF. From comparison of the weight loss values, it can be estimated that when more carbon is deposited on the catalyst surface during the reaction, less H is present in the structure of the carbon deposit. The HZ catalysts were characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy to investigate the structure of the coke formed on the surface of the catalysts during the MTH reaction. As shown in Fig. 6 , the IR spectra of all the catalysts exhibited typical peaks of aromatic-structured coke deposits at 1300–1700 cm−1. For instance, the IR peaks appearing at 1610, 1588, 1540, 1440, and 1365 cm–1 are associated with the C = C stretching vibration of unsaturated hydrocarbons, CH bending vibration of complex aromatics (so-called polycondensed aromatic coke species), CC stretching vibration of naphthalene, CH twisting vibrations of complex aromatics, and CH wagging vibrations of complex aromatics, respectively [45,48-51]. For all the HZSM-5 catalysts, it was revealed that aromatic-structured carbon was formed; however, the IR peak at 1588 cm–1 was slightly less intense for the HZ30-HF and HZ50-HF catalysts, indicating reduced formation of polycondensed aromatic species. The active sites in the MTH reaction are known to be acid sites that are uniformly distributed throughout the zeolite crystal [16]. Comparing the acid properties of the fresh catalysts and the carbon distribution to the products in the MTH reaction, the carbon distribution to aromatics and paraffin products was found to be the highest for the bare ZSM-5 catalysts without acid site removal, which had the highest number of acid sites (especially strong acid sites). The produced aromatic compounds block the pores of ZSM-5, with a pore size of approximately 5.5 Å in the 3D structure, causing a rapid decrease in the catalytic activity [9,52]. Therefore, rapid deactivation of the HZn catalysts during the MTH reaction is unavoidable. For the HZn-HF catalyst, which showed the greatest decrease in the number of acid sites, particularly strong acid sites, continuous oligomerization and aromatization of the -(CH2)- intermediates generated during the MTH reaction were not observed, resulting in a large amount of olefin products [53]. However, in the case of the HZn-TA catalysts, the number of strong acid sites in the pores did not decrease significantly; thus, formation of carbon deposits at the pore inlets was expected to be lowered, thereby prolonging the catalyst lifetime [54,55]. Moreover, it seems that chain growth in the pores was sufficient, and thus the C10+ products also increased. The HZn-HF catalysts had the smallest amount of carbon deposits (coke), despite having the longest reaction time, and the ratio of H/C in the products was relatively high, which can be expected because of the low production of aromatic compounds. Combining the results of the MTH reaction and the analysis of the carbon deposits of the spent catalysts after the reaction, it can be concluded that the main cause of deactivation of the HZSM-5 catalysts in the MTH reaction is coke formation, and the chemical properties of the catalysts, as well as the amount of coke, can be controlled by modifying the acid properties of the zeolite catalysts. 4 Conclusion To investigate effects of an acid modification of HZSM-5 zeoliteson performance and coke formation for methanol-to-hydrocarbon reaction, acid sites of selected HZSM-5 catalysts were selectively (HZn-TA) and non-selectively (HZn-HF) removed by using different acid solutions (Tartaric acid and ammonium hexafluorosilicate). The acid treatments applied for dealumination did not change the MFI structure, crystallinity, pore nature, and crystal shape of the bare HZSM-5 (HZn) samples. On the other hand, the acid nature was obviously affected by the acid treatments; the extensive decrease in all kinds of acid sites by the non-selective dealumination whereas the noticeable decrease in weak Lewis acid sites by the selective dealumination. The acid solutions used for the acid modification of the HZSM-5 catalysts also leaded to change in product selectivity for the MTH reaction as follows; high carbon distributions to the C2–C4 range olefins from the HZn-HF type catalysts, high carbon distributions to aromatic products (BTEX) from the HZn-TA type catalysts. These results are the clear evidence that the product selectivity for the MTH reaction is strongly affected by the acid nature, which can be facilitated by a proper post-acid treatment. For all the HZSM-5 catalysts, deactivation was caused by carbon deposits formed on the catalyst surface during the MTH reaction, and the amount and chemistry of carbon deposits were found to be directly related to the acidic nature of the HZSM-5 catalysts. For instance, the amount of carbon deposit from the spent catalysts were found to be increased in the order: HZn-TA > HZn > HZn-HF. Thus, one can expect that not only product selectivity but also catalyst deactivation rate, which are mainly caused by the amount and chemistry of carbon deposits on the surface or in the pore of the HZSM-5 catalyst during the MTH reaction, is properly controlled by the appropriate choice of the post acid treatment. coredata.dc:description: To study effects of different acid treatments with HZSM-5 zeolites on the chemistry of framework, acid nature, performance, and coke formation for methanol-to-hydrocarbon reaction, HZSM-5 with different Si/Al ratio were post treated with two different acid solutions (tartaric acid and ammonium hexafluorosilicate). After the post treatment with hexafluorosilicate (HZn-HF), it was found the extensive decrease in all kinds of acid sites owing to the non-selective dealumination, whereas the noticeable decrease in weak Lewis acid sites was found after the post treatment with tartaric acid (HZn-TA) resulted by the selective removal of the surface alumium. The result of the distingushed removal of Al from the bare HZSM-5 zeolites (HZn) also attributed the change in product selectivity for the MTH reaction as follows; high carbon distributions to the C2–C4 range olefins and low carbon distribution to C10+ species from the HZn-HF samples whereas high carbon distribution to BTEX from the HZn-TA samples. Analysis of the spent catalysts revealed the amount and chemistry of carbon deposits formed during the MTH reaction are directly related to the acidic nature of the HZSM-5 catalysts. For example, the amount of carbon deposit from the spent catalysts were found to be increased in the order: HZn-TA > HZn > HZn-HF. Therefore, among the bare and acid modified HZ catalysts, the HZn-HF type catalyst showed the least carbon deposition despite requiring the longest reaction time for the methanol conversion to reach 80%.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of acid modification of ZSM-5 catalyst on performance and coke formation for methanol-to-hydrocarbon reaction
